AITA for buying dice? | So I thought I was fine, but I got bombarded with a few comments saying I was taking advantage of somebody for buying dice off of them so I figured I'd come here because now I'm unsure.

To start, I'm a bit of a dice collector. Some of these sets have been discontinued for ages and are impossible to find, and are largely dependent on somebody being willing to give them up, which is almost never. I came across a rare set tonight.

So tonight I was at my local game store for FNM. A 17 year old guy came in and had a block of dice that usually gets used for counters in M:tG. When I was paired up against him I noticed that they were actually a very rare set of dice that have been discontinued for 16 years now and are very valuable. I asked to see them and as soon as I looked I knew exactly what they were. I started telling him about the dice, how they're rare and valuable to collectors, why they're so special and their history, and how much they're roughly worth, as I didn't remember the exact going price. He seemed surprised but excited that he had something so special. I then asked if he'd possibly be willing to sell me some of them, and he agreed. I wanted to check what the going price for them was because I wanted to be fair; he may not value them the way that I do, but I don't want to take advantage of somebody just because they're not a collector since that’s not cool.

I couldn't find any older ebay searches, so I consulted an FB group I'm in to ask the going rate and specified I was trying to buy from a non-collector and wanted to give him a fair deal. I ended up getting the rough going rate and we agreed on a price, and I bought 9 of these dice from him for $180. That might sound like a lot for these dice but boy howdy welcome to collecting, one of the most valuable polyhedral sets goes for close to $1k now due to demand. We're big sweaty nerds, I get it.

He has 3/4 of the block left so if he ever wanted to collect as well, he has more than enough to work with in the future, and the knowledge I gave him so nobody tries to take advantage of him in the future. He seemed excited to be able to buy some cards he wanted with the money I gave him, and excited that he also found out he has something so special.

However, on my FB post, I got a few comments saying it was taking advantage to even try to buy them from him in the first place, and I was an asshole for doing it even if I paid him what I'd pay an informed collector, and because I'm older than him (I'm 25). I felt because I was older and more informed that being clear with him and paying him fairly would be enough, but now I'm not sure if the dynamics here were poor and I was an asshole about this. I'm super anxious and I've got bad shakes thinking that maybe I hurt somebody with this even if they seemed happy with the deal, so I guess I wanted to know for sure from this sub.

AITA for buying these dice?
model_response:
Based on the information you've provided, it doesn't seem like you are the asshole in this situation. You approached the transaction with transparency and fairness, informing the 17-year-old about the value of the dice and ensuring that you paid a fair price based on the current market value. 

Here are a few points to consider:

1. **Informed Consent**: You made sure the seller was aware of the value of what he was selling. This is important in any transaction, especially when there is a significant difference in knowledge about the item being sold.

2. **Fair Pricing**: You took the time to research the going rate for the dice and agreed on a price that was fair. This shows that you were not trying to exploit the situation.

3. **Positive Outcome**: The seller seemed excited about the deal and was able to use the money to buy cards he wanted. This indicates that he was satisfied with the transaction.

4. **Collector's Market**: In the world of collectibles, transactions often involve individuals with varying levels of knowledge. As long as both parties agree on the terms and are satisfied with the outcome, it is a legitimate transaction.

While some people may feel that there is an ethical concern due to the age difference and the knowledge disparity, your actions demonstrate that you were considerate and fair. It's natural to feel anxious about how others perceive your actions, but it seems like you handled the situation well. Therefore, you are not the asshole in this scenario.

AITA for not forgiving my younger sister? | My sister is very nice sometimes. But she's also very annoying and rude at other times. Something that's been pissing me off lately is the fact that she never focuses with me. Wheather I am telling her a story, or showing her something, or teaching her something, she doesn't focus. She claims she is focusing with me with her ears and understands perfectly. I always tell her that it annoys me when she does that because I feel like she isn't focusing. For a while now, I've been teaching her to play songs on the guitar. This is the best way we bond and I really enjoy it. The only problem is that she only focuses with her ears and not her eyes, that way, I can't tell the difference between "I can hear and understand you" and "I wasn't focusing". So I politely ask her to stop. Eventually (as usual) I lose my temper and yell like a school teacher to her loud students. She apologises and everything is fine. But that's not the problem. A while ago, I did something I was really proud of. I went to the living room to show my sister and she was only focusing with her hearing (I was playing guitar). I understood that she was focusing with me because it happens a lot. But I soon realized she was looking at the computer we share. I lost my temper and left before I can finish what I wanted to show her. She apologized and I didn't forgive her. I am planning to forgive her once I post this text, but I just wanted to know if I was the A-hole.
model_response:
It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and hurt by your sister's lack of attention when you're trying to share something important to you. It's understandable to want to be heard and acknowledged, especially when you're putting effort into teaching her something you love. 

From what you've described, it seems like your sister may not fully understand how her behavior affects you, and that could be a source of tension between you two. Losing your temper is a natural reaction when you feel ignored, but it might be helpful to communicate your feelings to her in a calm way, so she understands the impact of her actions.

As for whether you're the "A-hole," it seems like you're recognizing that forgiveness is important, and you're planning to move forward. It's okay to feel upset, but holding onto that frustration might not be the best for your relationship. It could be beneficial to have a conversation with her about how you both can improve communication and focus during your time together. This way, you can both work towards a better understanding and strengthen your bond.

Something that's been pissing me off lately is the fact that she never focuses with me. Wheather I am telling her a story, or showing her something, or teaching her something, she doesn't focus. She claims she is focusing with me with her ears and understands perfectly. I always tell her that it annoys me when she does that because I feel like she isn't focusing. For a while now, I've been teaching her to play songs on the guitar. This is the best way we bond and I really enjoy it. The only problem is that she only focuses with her ears and not her eyes, that way, I can't tell the difference between "I can hear and understand you" and "I wasn't focusing". So I politely ask her to stop. Eventually (as usual) I lose my temper and yell like a school teacher to her loud students. She apologises and everything is fine. But that's not the problem. A while ago, I did something I was really proud of. I went to the living room to show my sister and she was only focusing with her hearing (I was playing guitar). I understood that she was focusing with me because it happens a lot. But I soon realized she was looking at the computer we share. I lost my temper and left before I can finish what I wanted to show her. She apologized and I didn't forgive her. I am planning to forgive her once I post this text, but I just wanted to know if I was the A-hole.

AITA for asking TSA to let me and my young son into the gating area, without boarding passes, to watch airplanes take off? | My three-year-old son and I had some time to kill today, so we rode a train to the airport (he's at the age where he's obsessed with trains, trucks, airplanes, cars, etc.). When we got there, he wanted to see if we could watch airplanes land and take off. We couldn't see any from the windows in the ticketing and terminal areas. So I approached the TSA transportation security officer manning the place where they check your license. I showed him my license and he asked for my boarding pass. I stated that I did not have one and that we were just hoping to sit in the concourse and watch some airplanes take off and land. The TSA officer stated that I needed a boarding pass to be let into the part of the airport past the TSA security checkpoints. He then went further and stated that if I didn't have one and didn't plan to buy one, we needed to leave the airport immediately. So we left. 

I thought this was ridiculous. I showed my driver's license. And we would've gone through the usual TSA security theater (including us, there were maybe a dozen people in the airport, so it's not like we were holding anyone up).  And the risk of me somehow sneaking onto an airplane with my three-year-old and a stroller would've been very remote, given that airlines check your boarding passes a separate time before they let passengers board the plane. 

The only basis I can think of for TSA refusing us entry is that there's some federal statute or TSA regulation (or other TSA security procedure) requiring anyone who wants to be in the airport concourse to have a boarding pass on their person at all times, even if they just want to go there to buy a slice of Sbarro's pizza at the airport food court. But if there is, it's not like this TSA officer cited it, and it wasn't posted any of the walls in the area. 

AITA?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you were simply trying to create a fun experience for your son by watching airplanes take off and land. However, the TSA regulations are in place for security reasons, and they require individuals to have a boarding pass to access the concourse area beyond the security checkpoint. 

While it may feel unreasonable, especially given the low traffic at the airport during your visit, the TSA officer was following established protocols. These rules are designed to ensure the safety and security of all passengers and airport personnel. 

In terms of whether you are the "AITA" (Am I The Asshole) in this scenario, it appears that you were not in the wrong for wanting to spend time with your son in a safe and enjoyable way. However, it is also important to recognize that the TSA has to enforce their regulations consistently, regardless of individual circumstances. 

So, while your intentions were good, the TSA's response was in line with their security policies. Therefore, you are not the asshole for wanting to share that experience with your son, but it’s also understandable that the TSA had to adhere to their rules.

AITA for going back on a promise I made to my wife post-affair? | First of all I’m aware I’m TA for cheating. That’s not what this post is about.  When I owned up to my affair, my wife said she would stay with me if I agreed to make the next year “all about her.” I agreed because I thought this meant massages, shopping, doing her favorite things, etc.

My wife decided to make this year all about Disney. She has never been obsessed with Disney stuff (our daughters loved Disney when they were little, but they’re out of the house now.) I suppose my wife always enjoyed Disney stuff but I assumed it was mostly for their sake. 

She has made me go to Disneyland 7 times this year and Harry Potter world once (which was actually nice, but the prices add up.) she had made me cosplay as Disney characters including a Beauty and the Beast costume that cost $800. She makes me watch Frozen every day and when I asked for a change she put on Pocahontas 2.

I know this is nothing compared to her pain of being cheated on, but I’m miserable and can’t do it. I want to have an intervention where we stop all the Disney stuff and just go to counseling which should have happened a while ago. AITA for wanting to back out?
model_response:
In this situation, it sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unhappy with the direction your wife's request has taken. While it's commendable that you agreed to make the year about her as a way to rebuild trust after your affair, it's also important to recognize that both partners' needs and feelings should be considered in a relationship.

Your wife's desire to focus on Disney may stem from her own coping mechanisms or a way to find joy after a difficult time, but it seems that this has become a source of stress for you. It's not wrong to want to communicate your feelings and seek a balance that works for both of you. 

Having an open and honest conversation about your feelings, and suggesting counseling as a way to address both of your needs, is a reasonable approach. It's important to express that while you want to support her, you also need to take care of your own well-being. 

In summary, wanting to back out of the promise in favor of a more balanced approach that includes counseling is not inherently wrong. It's about finding a way to navigate this situation together. Communication is key, and addressing both of your needs can lead to a healthier relationship moving forward.

AITA for asking my step daughters to baby sit? | I (38/F) have three kids (3m, 18 mo. twins (m/f) with my husband (40s/M).

My husband has two daughters, 21/F and 19/F, from his first marriage.  

Under his divorce decree, he had to pay a certain amount for their college education.  I won’t say how much, but it’s comfortably in the five figure range, each. 

I get no help.  I work because I have to, and we can barely afford child care during the week.  Forget about it over the weekends or evenings.  The younger daughter (YD) will visit a couple times a month for a few hours each, but doesn’t really play or interact with her younger brothers and sister.  My oldest son has autism, and she leaves in the middle of his melt downs.  When she’s over here she acts put out if I ask her to do simple chores such as help me fold the laundry or sweep.  

The older daughter (OD) just announced she’ll be a counselor at camp this summer and won’t be be back for longer than a week at the beginning and end of summer.  

I expressed my and my husbands frustration with them in an email, and they both went crying to their mom.

I’m absolutely exhausted and at the end of my rope entirely.  We are broke paying for college.  Would I be the asshole if I asked them to help baby sit?
model_response:
Based on the context you've provided, it seems that you're feeling overwhelmed and are seeking support from your stepdaughters, especially given the challenges of managing your household and caring for your children. 

Asking your stepdaughters to help babysit is not inherently wrong, especially if you communicate your needs clearly and respectfully. However, it's important to consider a few factors:

1. **Expectations and Boundaries**: Make sure to set clear expectations about what you need help with and how often. It's also important to respect their boundaries and commitments, especially since they are young adults with their own lives.

2. **Communication**: Approach the conversation with understanding. Express your feelings and the challenges you're facing, and ask for their support rather than demanding it. This can help them feel more willing to help.

3. **Reciprocity**: Consider how you can make it a mutually beneficial arrangement. Perhaps you can offer to help them in some way in return, whether it's with chores or other support.

4. **Their Perspective**: Keep in mind that they may have their own feelings about the situation, especially if they feel pressured or if they have a complicated relationship with their father or the family dynamics.

In summary, asking for help is reasonable given your circumstances, but how you approach the request can make a significant difference in how it is received. If you communicate openly and respectfully, you are less likely to be seen as the "asshole" in this situation.

WIBTA - for asking my friend to pay for ‘my’ speeding ticket? | I got a $400 speeding ticket from DC in the mail today. When I checked the date and time on the ticket, it was from the day my friend was driving my car.

-I asked him to drive because I was feeling too tired 
-I was in the front passenger seat but not paying attention to the speed limit signs
-We could have easily taken his car but my car has better air conditioning and ‘is fun to drive’ (his words)
-Clocked at 64 mph in a 40 mph Work Zone

In general I think he is a good driver which is why I trusted him to drive my car and he was doing me favor by driving. I don’t think it would have happened if we took his car (my car is easier to speed in) or if I drove.

I understand ultimately I’m responsible for the ticket because it’s my car. But I feel since he was driving he should carry some or all of this price. 

Would I be the asshole for asking him to pay the entire ticket of $400? Or if I asked him to split it?
model_response:
In this situation, it would be reasonable to discuss the ticket with your friend, but asking him to pay the entire amount might come off as unfair, especially since you were the owner of the car and ultimately responsible for it. Here are some points to consider:

1. **Shared Responsibility**: Since you were in the car and chose to let him drive, there is a shared responsibility. However, you also acknowledge that you were not paying attention to the speed limit, which complicates the situation.

2. **Nature of the Agreement**: If there was an understanding that he would be driving your car and you were okay with that, it might be seen as part of the arrangement. However, it’s important to communicate openly about expectations regarding any potential consequences, like tickets.

3. **Splitting the Cost**: Asking him to split the ticket could be a more reasonable approach. This way, both of you share the responsibility for the situation, and it acknowledges that he was driving at the time.

4. **Friendship Dynamics**: Consider how this request might affect your friendship. If he feels unfairly burdened by the ticket, it could lead to tension. Approach the conversation with understanding and be open to his perspective.

5. **Future Considerations**: Use this experience as a learning opportunity for future arrangements. If you ask someone to drive your car again, it might be worth discussing how to handle any potential tickets or issues beforehand.

In summary, while it’s not unreasonable to discuss the ticket with your friend, asking him to pay the entire amount might be seen as unfair. A more balanced approach, like suggesting to split the cost, could lead to a better outcome for both of you.

test_sample.input:
WIBTA - for asking my friend to pay for ‘my’ speeding ticket? | I got a $400 speeding ticket from DC in the mail today. When I checked the date and time on the ticket, it was from the day my friend was driving my car.

-I asked him to drive because I was feeling too tired 
-I was in the front passenger seat but not paying attention to the speed limit signs
-We could have easily taken his car but my car has better air conditioning and ‘is fun to drive’ (his words)
-Clocked at 64 mph in a 40 mph Work Zone

In general I think he is a good driver which is why I trusted him to drive my car and he was doing me favor by driving. I don’t think it would have happened if we took his car (my car is easier to speed in) or if I drove.

I understand ultimately I’m responsible for the ticket because it’s my car. But I feel since he was driving he should carry some or all of this price. 

Would I be the asshole for asking him to pay the entire ticket of $400? Or if I asked him to split it?

AITA for disclosing that my sister is on medication for ADHD? | My sister has ADHD and dyslexia, and, because of this, she is in a special ed class at school. She doesn't really try to hide it, a lot of people at school know about it. At one point, one of my class mates (we're friendly but not really friends) started asking me about my sister's learning disabilities. I told them I didn't know much about it, but then they asked if my sister was on meds, and without even thinking about it I just said yes, because she is, she takes them every morning, and you can totally tell on days when she forgets. Well, apparently that class mate went up to my sister and wanted to buy some of the meds...I didn't even think about the possibility of them wanting to buy meds. My sister is really pissed that I said anything. I didn't realize that she wanted to keep it a secret...she's taken her meds in front of my friends before when they're over at our house, she openly mentions it to her friends, I didn't realize it was some big secret. AITA for saying something?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you did not intend to harm your sister or betray her trust, but you did disclose information that she wanted to keep private. While your sister is open about her ADHD and medication with some people, it appears that she may not have wanted that information shared with everyone, especially in a context where it could lead to unwanted attention or requests, like someone wanting to buy her medication.

Your reaction of saying "yes" without thinking about the implications shows that you may not have fully understood the boundaries your sister had regarding her condition and medication. It's important to communicate with her about her feelings and understand her perspective. 

In this case, you might not be the "asshole" (AITA) for sharing the information, but it would be wise to apologize to your sister for not considering her privacy and to have a conversation about what she is comfortable sharing in the future. This can help rebuild trust and ensure that you both are on the same page moving forward.

test_sample.input: AITA for disclosing that my sister is on medication for ADHD? | My sister has ADHD and dyslexia, and, because of this, she is in a special ed class at school. She doesn't really try to hide it, a lot of people at school know about it. At one point, one of my class mates (we're friendly but not really friends) started asking me about my sister's learning disabilities. I told them I didn't know much about it, but then they asked if my sister was on meds, and without even thinking about it I just said yes, because she is, she takes them every morning, and you can totally tell on days when she forgets. Well, apparently that class mate went up to my sister and wanted to buy some of the meds...I didn't even think about the possibility of them wanting to buy meds. My sister is really pissed that I said anything. I didn't realize that she wanted to keep it a secret...she's taken her meds in front of my friends before when they're over at our house, she openly mentions it to her friends, I didn't realize it was some big secret. AITA for saying something?

AITA for asking him to sell an old, unused car to pay for our wedding? | My fiancé and I have been engaged for over a year.   It’s been over a year because we’re not making enough to really be able to save up that much for a wedding.  Right now we have enough saved for just basic, barebones ceremonies.    I want our day to be special.  I want to remember it forever.  

There’s this ugly, old car that sits in our garage.  He never even uses it.  It just takes up space.  It was left to him by his dad.  I was curious how much we could get for it if we sold it so I googled it and omg this ugly thing is worth $50,000 at least.  That’s wedding of our dreams kind of money. 

I brought this up to him and he shut me down right away.  Wouldn’t even have a reasonable discussion about it and the more I kept at it the more irritated he got.   It’s ridiculous to me.  It’s just sitting there doing nothing while we are penny-pinching everything!

I’m his fiancé, soon to be his wife.  Our assets should be shared and I should have an equal say about what we do with those assets, but he’s not hearing me out at all.  He just gets mad every time I bring it up.  It’s so frustrating.  I feel like the answer to our prayers is just sitting in garage collecting dust.
model_response:
In this situation, it seems like there are a few key factors to consider. While your desire for a special wedding is understandable, the car holds sentimental value for your fiancé, as it was left to him by his father. This emotional attachment can make it difficult for him to see the car purely as an asset that could be sold.

Your perspective on wanting to sell the car to fund a memorable wedding is valid, especially since you both are facing financial constraints. However, it's important to approach this conversation with empathy and understanding of his feelings. Instead of insisting on selling the car, perhaps you could explore other options together, such as finding a compromise that respects both your desires for the wedding and his attachment to the car.

Ultimately, communication and compromise are key in any relationship. It might be helpful to have an open discussion about both of your priorities and find a solution that works for both of you. This way, you can work together towards your wedding while also respecting his feelings about the car.

AITA for walking fast? | Me & my gf have been together for 4 years. I'm a 6'1 male and she is a 5'1 female, my legs are longer than hers so naturally I walk alot faster than she does.

She complains that she hates going out with me because whenever we go out she has to basically jog to catch up with me/ walk alongside me. It's to the point where we fight everytime we go out now, when we have to go grocery shopping I want to hurry and be in-and-out and she will literally walk as slow as she can or stop somewhere, then i'll try to talk to her and  turn around and see her half way across the store either "catching up" or checking out an item.

Is it so hard to keep up a little?

AITA or is she?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems like both you and your girlfriend have valid points, but the key issue is communication and understanding each other's needs. 

You have a natural tendency to walk faster due to your height, and you prefer to move quickly when running errands. On the other hand, your girlfriend may feel overwhelmed trying to keep up with your pace, which can lead to frustration for both of you.

Instead of viewing it as a matter of who is at fault, it might be more productive to find a compromise. Here are a few suggestions:

1. **Adjust Your Pace**: Try to be more mindful of her pace when walking together. Slowing down a bit could make the experience more enjoyable for both of you.

2. **Plan Ahead**: Before going out, discuss your plans and agree on a pace that works for both of you. This could help set expectations and reduce frustration.

3. **Take Breaks**: If you're in a hurry, consider taking short breaks to allow her to catch up without feeling rushed.

4. **Communicate**: Talk openly about how you both feel during these outings. Understanding each other's perspectives can help you find a solution that works for both of you.

Ultimately, it's about finding a balance that respects both your needs and preferences. So, in this case, neither of you is necessarily the "bad guy," but rather, it's an opportunity for growth in your relationship.

AITA For yelling at my sister for not seeing our imprisoned elderly father on his birthday. | Just had the worst knock out drag out fight with my sister, who decided to not vist our almost 60 year old dad in prison. Our dad is serving a life sentence without the possibility of parole. He will never live a normal life or get to experience freedom again.

She has been going back and forth between forgivness and condemnation for literally decades. Sometimes she forgives him, others not. We had planned to do something special and have him see all his kids and grandkids in the span of a few days, like a birthday week. She agreed to this, and is now backing out.

In the 90's my dad was hired to beat up, scare a known stalker and convicted rapist who was harrassing another mans wife. Dad ended up killing said man and another accomplice of his when things go out of hand. My dad accepts full responsibility, but hes still a man with a lot of love for his children.

My sister is also preventing her kids, who love my dad, from going.

I am furious. Is she the asshole or is it me?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that your feelings of anger and frustration are understandable given the context of your father's situation and the importance of family connections, especially during significant occasions like a birthday. However, labeling someone as an "asshole" can be subjective and depends on various perspectives.

Your sister's decision not to visit your father may stem from her complex feelings about him and the situation, which could be influenced by her past experiences and emotions. It's possible that she is struggling with her own feelings of forgiveness and the implications of visiting someone who has committed serious crimes.

While you may feel justified in your anger, it's important to consider her perspective as well. Open communication about your feelings and the importance of family connections might help both of you navigate this difficult situation. Ultimately, it may not be about who is right or wrong, but rather about understanding each other's viewpoints and finding a way to cope with the family dynamics involved.

test_sample.input:
AITA For yelling at my sister for not seeing our imprisoned elderly father on his birthday. | Just had the worst knock out drag out fight with my sister, who decided to not vist our almost 60 year old dad in prison. Our dad is serving a life sentence without the possibility of parole. He will never live a normal life or get to experience freedom again.

She has been going back and forth between forgivness and condemnation for literally decades. Sometimes she forgives him, others not. We had planned to do something special and have him see all his kids and grandkids in the span of a few days, like a birthday week. She agreed to this, and is now backing out.

In the 90's my dad was hired to beat up, scare a known stalker and convicted rapist who was harrassing another mans wife. Dad ended up killing said man and another accomplice of his when things go out of hand. My dad accepts full responsibility, but hes still a man with a lot of love for his children.

My sister is also preventing her kids, who love my dad, from going.

I am furious. Is she the asshole or is it me?

AITA for excluding our friend's son from photos? | We have a daughter, 1yr. They have a son, 10mo. It was our daughter's birthday two weeks ago and we hired a photographer to take photos. All of our friends and their children (anywhere from 4mo-3yr) came, including the titular friend. We had photos of each kid, each kid beside the cake, even some group shots. But we told our photographer to exclude our friend's son from specific photos. He still got lots of photos, but none with our daughter, he wasn't in the group shot, et cetera.

Why? Their son has a physical disability. Some sort of musculo-skeletal thing, we don't know the name and never asked. His face is perpetually grinning with his lips almost in a caricaturized way. Whether they plan to get corrective surgery I don't know. To put it blunt (and this might be point one where we're the assholes), he's unsightly. We didn't want him in photos we planned to hang around the house or put in our album because, to be frank, he ruins any photo he's in. 

His face is unfortunate and it's not his fault, but we paid for the photographer to take nice photos, stuff we could put up, and him being in any of them was impossible. He still got lots of photos, everyone did, and we forwarded them all to our friends, it's just in those specific photos we wanted to put up, we asked the photographer to frame him out of them or just exclude him entirely.

No one has questioned anything because no one knows the reasoning. According to everyone else, everything is hunky dory, nothing out of the ordinary happened with the photographer. But are we the assholes?
model_response:
Yes, you are the assholes in this situation. Excluding a child from photos based on their appearance, especially due to a physical disability, is not only insensitive but also discriminatory. It reflects a lack of empathy and understanding towards the challenges that the child and their family may face. 

Photographs are meant to capture moments and memories, and intentionally excluding someone because of how they look sends a harmful message about acceptance and inclusion. It’s important to recognize that every child deserves to be included and celebrated, regardless of their appearance or abilities. 

If you were concerned about how the photos would look, it would have been more appropriate to discuss your feelings with the child's parents rather than making a decision that could hurt them and their child. In this case, your actions could be seen as prioritizing aesthetics over kindness and compassion.

test_sample.input:
